title: How to Cook Hanger Steak

steps.headline: Heat a skillet and season the steaks.
steps.description: Place a heavy skillet on the stove and turn the heat to high. Pour in 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of vegetable oil and sprinkle six 7-ounce  (200 g) hanger steaks with salt and pepper.

steps.headline: Saute the steaks for 6 to 8 minutes.
steps.description: Place the hanger steaks into the hot skillet and cook them for 6 to 8 minutes. Turn them occasionally so they cook evenly. The steaks will be medium-rare to well done depending on how long you saute them. Transfer the steaks to a plate.

steps.headline: Rest the steaks and cook the shallots.
steps.description: Cover the steaks loosely with aluminum foil to rest while you make the sauce. Heat the skillet with the steak drippings over medium heat. Add 1 tablespoon (14 g) of the unsalted butter and 8 medium shallots that you've peeled and thinly sliced. Salt and pepper the shallots. Stir and cook them for 3 to 5 minutes so they become soft.

steps.headline: Stir in red wine and red wine vinegar.
steps.description: Pour in 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of red wine vinegar and let it cook until the liquid evaporates. Then pour in 1/2 cup (120 ml) of dry red wine. Bring the sauce to a boil and cook it until half of the liquid evaporates.

steps.headline: Finish the sauce and pour it over the steak.
steps.description: Take the sauce off the stove and stir in the last tablespoon (14 g) of unsalted butter and 2 tablespoons (7 g) of minced Italian parsley leaves. Slice the steaks against the grain and spread them out on the serving plates. Pour some of the shallot sauce over each steak and serve them right away.

methods.name: Grilling Hanger Steak with Garlic and Herbs

steps.headline: Trim and season the hanger steak.
steps.description:
Get out 2 pounds (907 g) of hanger steak and trim off any visible fat or silverskin (the tough white membrane on the outside of the meat). Place the steak in a shallow pan and rub it all over with 2 tablespoons (30 ml) of olive oil. Cover the steak with these seasonings:
2 tablespoons (17 g) whole peppercorns
4 thinly sliced garlic cloves
4 large roughly chopped sprigs of parsley
1 large thinly sliced shallot
1 tablespoon kosher salt

steps.headline: Marinate the steak for at least 2 hours.
steps.description: Put the seasoned steak into a seal-able plastic bag and squeeze out as much air as you can. Seal the bag and put the meat in the refrigerator to rest for at least 2 hours. If you want to prepare the meat in advance, you can marinate the meat overnight.

steps.headline: Prepare a hot grill.
steps.description: When you're ready to cook the steak, turn a gas grill on to the highest setting. If you're using charcoal, heat the coals and spread them across one half of the grate to create a two-zone grill. Preheat the grill for at least 10 minutes before you put the steaks on.

steps.headline: Salt the steak and grill them for about 8 minutes.
steps.description: Take the steak out of the marinade and sprinkle it with more kosher salt. Put the steak on the hot side of the grill and let it cook for about 8 minutes. You should turn the steak every once in a while so it cooks evenly. The steak should be about 125 to 130 degrees F (50 to 55 degrees C) for medium-rare to medium.

steps.headline: Rest the steak and slice it.
steps.description: Place the cooked steak on a plate and cover it loosely with aluminum foil. Let the steak rest for 5 minutes so it finishes cooking and is easier to slice. Use a sharp knife to cut the steak against the grain into strips. Serve it immediately.

methods.name: Broiling Balsamic and Soy Marinated Hanger Steak

steps.headline: Combine the marinade.
steps.description:
Place all of your balsamic soy marinade ingredients in a medium mixing bowl and stir them until they're combined. You'll need:
1/2 chopped onion. 3 cloves chopped garlic. 1/4 cup (60 ml) olive oil. 1/4 cup (60 ml) balsamic vinegar. 1/4 cup (60 ml) soy sauce. 1 tablespoon (15 g) Dijon mustard. 1 tablespoon (2 g) fresh rosemary. 1 teaspoon (5 g) salt. 1/2 teaspoon (2 g) ground black pepper.

steps.headline: Marinate the steak for at least 30 minutes.
steps.description: Put 1 1/2 pounds (680 g) of trimmed hanger steak into a big seal-able plastic bag and pour the marinade into it. Squeeze as much of the air out of the bag as you can and seal it shut. Shake the bag a little so the steak is completely covered with the marinade. Place it in the refrigerator to marinate for at least 30 minutes. You can marinate the steak in advance. Store the marinating meat for up to 2 days.

steps.headline: Turn on the broiler and prepare the pan.
steps.description: When you're ready to cook the steaks, turn on the broiler and spread a little bit of oil onto the broiler pan so the steaks don't stick. Remove the marinating steak from the refrigerator. Lift them out of the bag so the excess marinade drips bag into the bag. Place the steaks on the oiled broiler pan.

steps.headline: Broil the hanger steak for 7 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Place the broiler pan under the broiler so the steak is about 2 to 3 inches (5 to 7 cm) away from the heat. Set a timer for 7 to 12 minutes and let the steak broil. Turn it about halfway through the cooking time so it cooks evenly. The steak should be cooked to medium-rare, about 130 degrees F (55 degrees C). If you overcook hanger steak, it will become very tough.

steps.headline: Rest and slice the steak.
steps.description: Remove the steak from under the broiler and place a piece of aluminum foil loosely over it. Let the steak sit for 10 minutes. Resting the steak will make the juices redistribute within the meat and will let it finish cooking. Carefully slice the meat against the grain and serve it immediately. If you slice it with the grain, the steak will be chewy and difficult to eat.
